TextView.android:text: Comparative form does exactly what its name sets out to do - it compares two nouns by saying some attributive is not the same between them. English also has a comparative form, in English, we affix an '-er' to the adjective.
The apple is bigger than the kiwi.\nMy car is faster than yours\nJohn got better grades than I did

Comparative form indicates that an aspect is not equal between two items or groups. In the case above, an apple is unequal in size as to that of a kiwi, and is therefore larger in size. An apple is larger than a kiwi. A kiwi is smaller than an apple.
In Irish, we do not affix an '-er' to the adjective, instead we follow a certain format:
Níos + adjective in feminine singular genitive
Once you know what the adjectival form is from the table below, it never changes unless it's one of the few exceptions in the language.
Below is a table of commonly changing to the feminine singular genitive form of the adjective.
Ending in a consonant and can be palatalised and add an -e:
glic - níos glice,\nramhar - níos raimhre\ndearg - níos deirge
Adjectives ending in -ach gets changed to -aí:
aisteach - níos aistí\nsalach - níos salaí\ngaelach - níos gaelaí
Adjectives ending in a vowel remain the same
The following adjectives are irregular in their comparative form and must be learned appropriately:
Is mó is fearr é ná inné\nIt's better than yesterday
Ba lú ba dóichí é ná riamh\nIt was less likely than ever
An fear is mó cáil\nThe most famous man

'Ná' is a frequent word in Irish that corresponds to the equivalent English 'than' when used to compare two objects or groups. Consider the example below that corresponds to the first set of examples under this heading. Note that the second noun normally takes an emphatic form to stress that the situation differs to what was previously thought by bringing new information to the context.
Tá an t-úll níos mó ná an cíobhaí\nTá mo ghluaisteán níos tapúla ná do chuid ghluaisteánsa\nFuair Seán torthaí níba fearr ná a fuair mise
Lú when used with another adjective in the general form or abstract noun forms a softener, or more simply, makes the following item appear less harsh and less severe, or more uncertain if positive.

Is lú is maith é
It's better, I guess

Is lú is sean é
It's not so old
Verbs following the comparative form are linked by any of the clause linkers below within the direct relative clause form for the verb.
Faighim milseáin níos minicí ná mar a fhaigheann tú\nI get sweets more frequently than you
Some phrases in English take the comparative form ('It's getting better'). In Irish, there are verbs that express this using a construct.

Tá sé ag dul i méid
It's getting bigger

Tá sé ag dul i bhfeabhas
It's getting better

Tá sé ag dul i laghad
It's getting smaller

In order to express than something is 'much bigger', 'a bit bigger' etc; Irish has words to fulfill these roles as does English. These words are placed before 'níos', ie 'cuid mhaith níos mó' 'a good bit bigger'.

i bhfad
quite a bit

mórán
a bit

cuid mhaith
a good bit

'Níos' only reflects the present and future tenses in Irish when making a comparison, note that it is also a shortened form of 'ní is'. In order to make a comparison that resides in a different time, such as past, conditional or otherwise, another word is used: 'níba'.
Bhí an torradh níba mhó ná a cheap mé\nThe result was bigger than I thought
Bhí an torradh ní b'fhearr ná mar a cheap mé\nThe result was better than I thought
Tá an torradh níos fearr ná mar a cheapann sé\nThe result is better than he thinks
When the copula is used, the word níba/níos is not used. Remember that the copula is used for topics and items that don't change, and are always in this state regardless of time within its existence.
Is/ba + comparative form + X + ná + Y

Is áille an ghealach ná an ghrian
The moon is prettier than the sun

B'fhearr liom dul
It'd be better for me to go
